So relieved to hear that I'm not alone suffering from symptoms of Beta Thalassemia Minor (BTM).I'm 19 years of age, and was diagnosed with BTM since birth.  My mother has it, and so have her all her sisters as well as my maternal grandmother.In terms of appearance, possibly due to BTM, I have always had dark circles under my eyes regardless of how much sleep I get - it's really annoying when people keep telling me to get some sleep even though I normally sleep more than everyone else.  What's queer is that those circles occasionally disappear when I get the least sleep.  I have the darkest skin complexion in the family and can get tanned very easily.  People close to me can't help but notice that I seem to have a non-maturing "babyface" and that I look about two years younger than I actually am - great for women but it's not something to boast about especially if you're a guy.  I'm not sure if this has something to do with lesser effects of bone deformation that Major patients suffer from.Symptoms-wise, I have always had the dreaded chronic tiredness/fatigue that nearly everyone mentioned here.  I used to sleep for 10 hours every day during childhood and I need 8 hours per night currently.  I also get tired easily and find it extremely difficult to wake up in the early morning.  My sleep patterns have never been routine - I tend not to be able to sleep until late in the night and get up just before noon or after.  I always seem to have this cotton wool feeling in my head, as if a cloud is trapped inside.  During exercise, I have always been least fit, going out of breath really quickly and having low endurance in strenuous activities like middle-distance running, due to tiredness.  In relation to depression, I have always felt less enthusiastic about life compared to others and pessimistic in general.  During childhood, I was like a complete introvert with extremely low confidence and highly emotionally dependent on others.  Currently, I tend to have emotional swings when I'm tired and have occasional crying outbursts towards people close to me.  Other than that, signs of depression have gotten a lot better than what I had as a kid.  About cold feet, I tend to get it a lot though it doesn't bother me at all.  In the past, I used to wear more than everyone else - in primary school, I wore 3 to 4 layers of clothing during winter when everyone else wore like 2.  It's really strange now though, as I'm not susceptible to feeling cold anymore over the years, often wearing less than most in winter months.Doctors should really take BTM much more seriously.  I get the usual yada yada about more exercise, sufficient sleep and meals with no help at all.  Blood tests, urine tests and health check-ups all say that I'm completely healthy and normal - all apart from having BTM, which supposedly does not require any attention at all, and that I'm "just like a normal person", as told by nurses and physicians.There isn't much information on the Internet about BTM, apart from blood transfusions for Major patients and articles about illnesses with similar symptoms.  Someone else earlier mentioned treatment by Chinese medicine: http://www.itmonline.org/arts/thalassemia.htm - I might give this a try.  To me, it sounds like the only proposed treatment on the web, though I would first clarify this with a Chinese medical doctor.  I've tried iron supplements recently which have alleviated a bit of tiredness though I stopped after having serious side-effects like nausea and black stool.  Not sure whether I should try it again as iron supplements are supposedly relatively toxic to Thalassemia patients with iron building up easily in the body.I really hope doctors would give more research into BTM as it has substantial symptoms.  I'm still in search of some medication or diet that would alleviate tiredness/fatigue, and of course for BTM in general.Any help would be greatly appreciated.

(I would be halted by heart palpitations and heavy breathing as if I was starving for oxygen.)  I could not learn to swim because I felt that I was grasping for oxygen after swimming  very short distance - 20 feet - and literally having a dizzy and sinking feeling - that was scary.As I got older (I'm going on 55 now) I found that my concentration would be fragmented easily. My ability to walk up stairs is challenged -six flights of stairs and I have to stop as I start panting heavy with heart palpitations. (I am slightly above my normal weight - 5' 9" and 175 Lbs.I also experience shortness of breath and tiredness that reduced my enthusiasm for exercise which, in turn, negatively impacts on my health. I also experience long colds and flus and fear infections as I have longer recuperation than normal folks. I also have numbness on the sides of my thighs and experienced occasional cold extremities and sensations when others do not.We share a similar problem and history. We had various advice from physicians over many years that range from denial of symptoms to serious issue. The truth lies somewhere in the middle: our stamina, alertness, suseptability to common colds/flus and mental faculties are more challenged than those without BTM.The key to quality of life is to manage our lifestyles to accommodate our special condition. Although we share BTM we experience variable degrees of similar symptoms. The differences can be a result of severity of genetic abnormality of our BTM RBCs and our ability to discipline ourselves to focus on diet, moderate exercise and adequate rest. We can also consider, especially younger members of our group, to consider career choices that do not exacerbate our symptoms - high stamina and high stress work tend to tax our concentration and increase our tiredness and induce anxiety and, in worst cases, depression.As we age we tend to be more susceptible to disease. It is not uncommon for those of us in mid-age (over 45) to start attracting more than one health condition.  In my case, I have excess pleural in lining of my right lung.  I also have an elongated spleen - about 2 inches (5 cm) longer than normal. My BTM makes my other organs work harder. (I also had experienced random heart palpitations that would scare me. I went for tread-mill, 24 hr. recorder, and ultrasound testing that had little results as I would show on the low side of normal and most doctors - in my experience (Canada) at least - do not get concerned about systemic health problems that fall close to normal.Our health care challenge is that doctors are trained in western traditions to treat acute and emergency issues very well but less inclined or proficient to service those of us that have lower quality of life experiences due to genetic disorders that are not  life threatening.I controlled my symptoms by taking 1MG of Vitamin C (calcium asorbate) per day for many years. I stopped taking 1 Mg of Vitamin C per day about one year ago (2007) when I had a kidney stone that was very painful to eliminate - I went to hospital emergency for pain relief and CAT scans that found a stone passing. I resumed my 1 Mg Vitamin C today to counter my BTM symptoms as I also have an infection in my right ear that is being treated with 500mg of Amoxicillin 3 x per day -15 day treatment.I try to focus on control and management. When I am ill I reassure myself that the length of recovery is not because I have a serious illness. My recovery time is due mainly to my BTM disorder. By rationalizing health challenges as genetic we accept that our role is to manage our diet, exercise, rest, career plans and, especially, mental health to improve our quality of life with BTM.Focus on managing what you can control - diet, etc., and accept what we can not, as yet, change - BTM. Remember, we are in this together. Best wishes.Bob

So, I've done some research on my paleness and dark circles under the eyes. Doctors have told me and my family that it has nothing to do with thalassemia...Well, wrong again. We have hemolytic anemia which means our red blood cells break down at a faster rate. One of the by products of this break down is bilirubin, it is yellow in colour and responsible for jaundice.Now, with hemolytic anemia the bilirubin levels are always slightly elevated. To get rid of it you need the sun. When bilirubin reacts to sunlight the entire structure of it changes and it becomes much more water soluble making it easier for the body to metabolise it.Also, look into gluceronic acid. It makes molecules water soluble in the body. Bilirubin can be conjugated with gluceronic acid.

Hey guys, I'm a medical student, and I too have b-thal minor (trait).  I actually found out via a random cbc a year ago.  Some of the symptoms you guys describe on here can't possibly be from b-thal minor.  This condition affects nothing more than your rbc's, and it's very possible that you may have something else going on that you should be checked out for. This disease will not make you more prone to becoming sick and catching the cold (this would most likely involve a wbc, or nutrient abnormality), cause seizures (which can be from a number of things, like electrolyte imbalance, trauma, etc., but not rbc dysfunction), or celiac's disease (which is autoimmune and has nothing to do with your rbc's).However, cold hands and feet, tiredness, slight trouble breathing, and minor exercise intolerance can all be attributable to b-thal minor due to the slight microcytic anemia it causes.  If you have a hemoglobin concentration below 8, then there is something else going on (you could have iron deficiency on top of b-thal minor, but usually b-thal minor patients have relatively normal, to slightly decreased levels- usually not lower than 10). It's important to realize that just because we all have b-thal minor does not mean we all have the same degree of the condition.  Many mutations have been demonstrated in the genes coding for beta hemoglobin, and while some may have more severe forms (with possible deletion of the beta chain), others may have forms of lesser severity.  However, b-thal minor is defined as only having 1 genomic copy of an abnormal beta chain, as 2 (one from your mother and the other from your father) can be interpreted as B-thal intermedia or major depending on the mutations present.That being said, even the most severe forms of b-thal minor leave us with 1 perfectly good copy of the beta chain, so never should this condition become totally catastrophic and crippling, as some of you seem to fear.  I personally have constant cold hands and feet, but there is nothing major to worry about with b-thal minor.  It does not weaken your immune system, cause autoimmune disorders, seizures, stomach pains etc.  If you are experiencing symptoms other than mild fatigue, cold hands and feet, and mild grogginess (all of which can be attributable to severe forms of b-thal minor), then there may be some other condition going on that you should have checked out.If you plan on having kids, it's also important to have your partner get a hemoglobin electrophoresis to assess if he/she also has the trait.  If both of you have it, then there is a 25% you kids will be normal, a 50% chance they will have b-thal minor (like yourself), and a 25% chance that they could have b-thal major- which is really bad and requires lifelong blood transfusions, possible bone marrow transplant, and a vastly shortened life expectancy.  So, it's definitely important to have your partner checked out before having kids.Hope this was informative :) I wanted to just to relax your nerves a bit, as this is really nothing to be overly concerned with, save the small possibility of mild fatigue, and symptoms I discussed.  And as a small plus, if you're an African traveler and develop malaria, you will suffer a lesser degree of complications because all forms of malaria require a normal functioning b-chain.  This is not to say you cannot get malaria (you can, since you still have 1 good b-chain gene), but that if you do get it, it probably wouldn't kill you (likewise for sickle cell).  Also, a few studies have suggested that the smaller size of our rbc's (microcytic anemia) put us at a decreased risk for stroke and heart disease since they're less likely to get "hung-up" and "tangled up" in blood vessels, but again this is not to say you are immune to dying from a stroke or heart disease, just that you may have a slight reduced risk :).

I am a 39 year old female who was diagnosed with Beta-Thalassemia when I was 12.  I am so frustrated with medical professionals continuing to say that people with Thalassemia minor should present no symptoms.  This is just not true.  I have several people in my family who suffer from this and we all have much the same symptoms, ie. fatigue, dizziness, palpatations, scoliosis, severe bone/joint pain, memory/concentration difficulties, blurred vision, and we easily get sick.  Our HG levels get very low following instances of illness or high stress and the symptoms get progressively worse with age.  Our quality of life has suffered due to this disorder.Iron supplements are not the answer unless your doctor has run a full iron study on you and has determined that you are iron deficient.  I have been seeing a hematolgist for 2 years who was prescribing high doses of iron.  The result of the iron supplementation is that I now have hemochromotosis (Iron Overload!)The real challenge for people with Thalassemia is in finding a medical professional who will listen to you and will not make you feel that you are a hypochondriac.  Doctors should be able to treat this condition.  They know what causes it and they know it results in anemia, so there should be a viable treatment for it.   More studies need to be done on this disorder and treatments need to be found!

zero motivation.  I need at least ten hours of sleep a night or else I am in a fog all day, can barely keep my eyes open and require a nap at some point in the day.  Does anyone else have excessive doctor they can only tell me I am perfectly healthy and the only things to work on is my iron, vit a,c, and d levels.  For those of you looking for some sort of iron supplements I would say NO or at least find a great Hemotologist who has knowledge of this problemto give you proper advice.  Our blood is misshapen and to the body looks unhealthy.  Therefore, the spleen tends to recycle a lot more blood then "normal" people's do, which means you can easily have a buildup of minerals, including iron which can be toxic.  My great uncle nearly died of this after receiving a blood transfusion with iron supplemation after a car accident.  I tend to get "spleen cramps" and some Thalassemia suffers opt to get their spleen removed because it is so overactive.  Someone also asked if there is a relation to Thalassemia and Leukemia, and the answer is no, although back in the day they believed it to be true.  My grandfather was not allowed to fight in WWII because the doctors believed he would develop Leukemia since he had Thalassemia, but again, it is just our misformed blood.Not only do I suffer from fatigue but I also am easily out of breath.  The worst when I partake in cardio exercise, which has always been embarassing in gym class and have not been accepted onto any sports team because of it.  I just look lazy and out of shape when really our blood does not absorb oxygen and glucose properly.  This is why we get out of breath easily and why our muslces cramp and fatigue easily.  I also have symptoms similar to hypoglycemia, and if I don't eat regularly I feel sick and faint.  I do have fainting spells, usually if I feel over-heated or if I stand too long, although a lot of the times it seems random.  I am both heat and cold sensitive; in the summer I tend to become dehydrated and sun sick easily, and in the winter no amount of layers of clothes can keep me warm, my hands and keep are ice cold to the touch and within.I suffer from depression, anxiety, panic disorder, ocd, and insomnia.  There is a long line of mental illness in my family but it tends to be just one disease per person, and I seem to have every disease that has ever existed in my family.  I'm wondering if maybe I have just underlying depression that is worsened by the thalassemia.  I have probably tried about 8 different medications for these problems but nothing seems to work completely.  It is VERY interesting to me that most of you suffer from some form of depression.I also have had heart palpatations but it has been so rare I never thought twice about it.  It happens 99% of the time after I have a long hot shower;  I feel overheated, get the feeling like im going to pass out ( I call it fade to black because My vision slowly-well, fades to black) and when I lay down to avoid passing out My heart beats rapidly, then stops beating for a sec, and rapid again.  This only happens a couple times a year so I figured... whatever.I feel like I could go on forever with my symptoms, but long story short I'm glad to see that I'm not the only one who has suspected that this "asymptomatic" disease does in fact carry many many problems.  It definately varies from person to person so it is possible that we are definately the minority which is why it hasnt really been looked into.  I know that my mother and grandfather have minimal symptoms if any, thew only thing my mother has had a problem with is the breathing.I already had a dr appt set for monday for something else, but I think I'm going to print this out and show them I'm not crazy!! haha!best wishes to all of you!  There is no cure, and everyone feels different with this disease, so my best advice is to monitor yourself closely to figure out what is best for you in connection with exercise, diet, etc.  (I personally take long walks for cardio and strength training has always kept me fit and trim.  I also eat very healthy and feel sick when I eat over-processed foods.  Just sayin')  I still feel like sh*t every day, but I know it is an ongoing process.Thank you to all of you for posting your experiences!!!!!!
